facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 632 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 632 of 1966.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and Order dated April 14, 1964 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in case referred No. 46 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and Order dated April 14, 1964 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in case referred No. 46 of 1962.

facts.text: The respondent is a Hindu Undivided Family consisting of K. Ankineedu and his two sons.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, hereinafter called the assessee was a Hindu Undivided Family companysisting of K. Ankineedu and his two sons.

facts.text: For the assessment year 1949-50 corresponding to the previous financial year ending March 31, 1949, the assessee submitted a return.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1949-50 companyresponding to the previous financial year ending March 31, 1949, the assessee submitted a return in response to a numberice sent to him.

facts.text: The Income-tax Officer computed assessee's total income as Rs. 2,429/- which was below the taxable limit and assessee was declared not liable to pay income-tax.

anchor.surface_text: in response to a numberice sent to him. The Income-tax Officer companyputed his total income as Rs. 2,429/- only which was below the taxable limit and so the assessee was declared number liable to pay income-tax.

facts.text: Original assessment made on February 10, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: original assessment made on February 10, 1950.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer had information that assessee had done business as procurement agent for the Government and earned large profits which escaped assessment.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequent to the assessment, the Income-tax Officer had information that the assessee had done some business as pro- curement agent for the Government and in this business he had earned large profits which had escaped assessment.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer issued notice under s. 34 of the Income-tax Act, 1922 on March 22, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly he issued a numberice under s. 34 of the Income-tax Act, 1922  hereinafter called the Act  on March 22, 1957.

facts.text: Notice under s.34 issued to assessee in status of individual.

anchor.surface_text: In response to the numberice the assessee made a return on April 30, 1957. Prior to the issue of the above numberice the Income-tax Officer had taken the view in the assessment made for the year 1954-55 that the companyrect status of the assessee was number Hindu Undivided Family but his status was individual.

facts.text: Assessee filed return on April 30, 1957 in response to first notice.

anchor.surface_text: In response to the numberice the assessee made a return on April 30, 1957.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner held assessee's status as Hindu Undivided Family for 1954-55.

anchor.surface_text: As the proceedings under this numberice were companytinuing, but before the assessment companyld be made, the Appellate Assistant Commissioner in the appeal for the assessment year 1954-55 accepted the companytention of the assessee and held that the. status of the assessee was that of Hindu Undivied Familyand number individual.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer issued fresh notice under s.34 on February 12, 1958 served same day to assessee as Hindu Undivided Family.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter,the Income-tax Officer issued a fresh numberice under s. 34 on February 12, 1958 which was served on the assessee on the same day.

facts.text: Return filed on February 28, 1958 pursuant to second notice.

anchor.surface_text: A return in pursuance of the second numberice was duly filed on February 28, 1958

facts.text: Assessment made under s.34 on August 16, 1958 in status of Hindu Undivided Family including Rs. 60,000/- escaped income.

anchor.surface_text: and the assessment was ultimately made under s. 34 of the Act in the status of Hindu Undivided Family on August 16, 1958. In this assessment, a sum of Rs. 60,000/- was included as the income escaping from the original assessment.

facts.text: Assessee appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner contending proceedings under s.34 invalid due to limitation after 8 years from previous year.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee preferred an appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and companytended that the proceedings under- s. 34 of the Act were number valid because numbernotice companyld be issued after the expiry of 8 years from the close of the previous year as distinct from the assessment year.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner accepted assessee's contention on limitation and held proceedings invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner accepted the companytention raised by the assessee and held that the proceeding was invalid.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal held limitation from end of assessment year, overruled AAC, held second notice valid, return to first notice invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer took the matter in appeal before the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal and claimed that -the period of limitation for starting proceedings under S. 34 was to be companynted from the end of the assessment year and number from the end of the previous year. The Tribunal accepted his companytention ... Accordingly the Appellate Tribunal held that the assessment made under the second numberice was legally valid.

facts.text: Tribunal remanded appeal to AAC for merits.

anchor.surface_text: Since the Appellate Assistant Commissioner did number deal with the merits of the assessment the Appellate Tribunal remanded the appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner for being dealt with on merits.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal stated case to High Court on question: Whether assessment in pursuance of notice under s.34 on 12-2-1958 is valid.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the assessee the Appellate Tribunal stated case to the High Court on the following question of law Whether, on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the assessment in pursuance of the numberice issued under s. 34 on 12-2-1958 is a valid assessment

facts.text: High Court held first notice dated March 22, 1957 not invalid, second notice illegal, assessment illegal.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the first numberice dated March 22, 1957 was number invalid in law and companysequently the issue of the second numberice on February 12, 1958 was illegal and the assessment made in pursuance of that numberice was also illegal.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds assessee's correct status is Hindu Undivided Family.

anchor.surface_text: The companyrect status of the assessee was that of Hindu Undivided Family as was held by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner in the assessment for the year 1954-55

facts.text: First notice under s.34 issued on March 22, 1957 in status of individual, sanction obtained on that basis.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that the Income-tax Officer issued the first numberice under s. 34 of the Act on March 22, 1957 to the assessee in the status of individual. ... It appears that on February 13, 1957 the Income-tax Officer had applied for the sanction of the Commissioner

facts.text: Proceedings under first notice invalid and ultra vires due to wrong status.

anchor.surface_text: In this state of facts we are of opinion that the proceeding taken under the first numberice under s. 34 of the Act was invalid and ultra vires.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside High Court judgment dated April 14, 1964 and answers question in affirmative.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly allow this appeal, set aside, the judgment of the High Court of Andhra Pradesh dated April 14, 1964 and hold that the question of law referred to the High Court should be answered in the affirmative and against the assessee.

anchor.surface_text: Under the scheme of the Income-tax Act the Individual and the Hindu Undivided Family are treated as separate units of assess- ment and if a numberice under s. 34 of the Act is wrongly issued to the assessee in the status of an individual and number in the companyrect status of Hindu Undivided Family the numberice is illegal and all proceedings taken under that numberice are ultra vires and without jurisdiction.

issues.text: whether it was competent for the Income-tax Officer to issue the second notice dated February 12, 1958 and continue proceedings thereon ignoring the return already filed by the assessee in pursuance of the first notice under the same section

anchor.surface_text: The question presented for determination in this appeal is whether it was competent for the Income-tax Officer to issue the second notice dated February 12, 1958 and continue proceedings thereon ignoring the return already filed by the assessee in pursuance of the first notice under the same section.

issues.text: whether the proceedings under s. 34 of the Act were not valid because no notice could be issued after the expiry of 8 years from the close of the previous year as distinct from the assessment year

anchor.surface_text: In this state of facts we are of opinion that the proceeding taken under the first notice under s. 34 of the Act was invalid and ultra vires.

issues.text: whether under the scheme of the Income-tax Act the Individual and the Hindu Undivided Family are treated as separate units of assessment such that a notice under s. 34 wrongly issued to the assessee in the status of an individual instead of Hindu Undivided Family renders the notice illegal and proceedings ultra vires and without jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: Under the scheme of the Income-tax Act the Individual and the Hindu Undivided Family are treated as separate units of assess- ment and if a notice under s. 34 of the Act is wrongly issued to the assessee in the status of an individual and not in the correct status of Hindu Undivided Family the notice is illegal and all proceedings taken under that notice are ultra vires and without jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: It was pointed out by Mr.S. T. Desai on behalf of the assessee that both the notices under s.34 of the Act were in identical terms and were addressed to the assessee in his name and the issue of the second notice made no difference in its contents to the knowledge of the assessee. It was also contended that the assessee filed his return in the status of Hindu Undivided Family in response to the first notice and the Income-tax Officer ought not to have ignored that return.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: mberice under s. 34 of the Act on March 22, 1957 to the assessee in the status of individual. The Appellate Tribunal has stated in para 3 of the state

arguments.claim: under scheme of Income-tax Act, Individual and Hindu Undivided Family are separate units of assessment; notice under s.34 wrongly issued to individual not HUF makes notice illegal and proceedings ultra vires and without jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: Under the scheme of the Income-tax Act the Individual and the Hindu Undivided Family are treated as separate units of assess- ment and if a notice under s. 34 of the Act is wrongly issued to the assessee in the status of an individual and not in the correct status of Hindu Undivided Family the notice is illegal and all proceedings taken under that notice are ultra vires and without jurisdiction.

arguments.claim: submission of return by assessee in HUF status in response to first notice does not make difference to character of proceedings which are illegal and ultra vires

anchor.surface_text: It was contended by Mr. S. T. Desai on behalf of the assessee that the return was filed by the assessee in response to the first notice in the character of Hindu Undivided Family. But the submission of the return by the assessee will not make any difference to the character of the proceedings in pursuance of the first notice which must be held to be illegal and ultra vires for the reasons already stated.

arguments.claim: Income-tax Officer legally justified in ignoring first notice and return thereto; assessment in pursuance of second notice dated February 12, 1958 valid

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of the opinion that the Income-tax Officer was legally justified in ignoring the first notice issued under s. 34 of the Act and the return filed by the assessee in response to that notice and consequently the assessment made by the Income- tax Officer in pursuance of the second notice issued on February 12, 1958 was a valid assessment.

holdings.text: the proceeding taken under the first notice under s. 34 of the Act was invalid and ultra vires

anchor.surface_text: In this state of facts we are of opinion that the proceeding taken under the first notice under s. 34 of the Act was invalid and ultra vires.

holdings.reasoning_summary: First notice issued to assessee in status of individual despite correct status being HUF; sanction obtained on individual basis; proceedings lack jurisdiction.

holdings.text: Under the scheme of the Income-tax Act the Individual and the Hindu Undivided Family are treated as separate units of assessment and if a notice under s. 34 of the Act is wrongly issued to the assessee in the status of an individual and not in the correct status of Hindu Undivided Family the notice is illegal and all proceedings taken under that notice are ultra vires and without jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: Under the scheme of the Income-tax Act the Individual and the Hindu Undivided Family are treated as separate units of assess- ment and if a notice under s. 34 of the Act is wrongly issued to the assessee in the status of an individual and not in the correct status of Hindu Undivided Family the notice is illegal and all proceedings taken under that notice are ultra vires and without jurisdiction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory scheme treats Individual and HUF as distinct units for assessment; notice to incorrect unit deprives jurisdiction over correct unit.

holdings.text: the submission of the return by the assessee will not make any difference to the character of the proceedings in pursuance of the first notice which must be held to be illegal and ultra vires for the reasons already stated.

anchor.surface_text: It was contended by Mr. S. T. Desai on behalf of the assessee that the return was filed by the assessee in response to the first notice in the character of Hindu Undivided Family. But the submission of the return by the assessee will not make any difference to the character of the proceedings in pursuance of the first notice which must be held to be illegal and ultra vires for the reasons already stated.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Filing return in correct status does not cure jurisdictional defect in notice issued to wrong status.

holdings.text: the Income-tax Officer was legally justified in ignoring the first notice issued under s. 34 of the Act and the return filed by the assessee in response to that notice and consequently the assessment made by the Income- tax Officer in pursuance of the second notice issued on February 12, 1958 was a valid assessment.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of the opinion that the Income-tax Officer was legally justified in ignoring the first notice issued under s. 34 of the Act and the return filed by the assessee in response to that notice and consequently the assessment made by the Income- tax Officer in pursuance of the second notice issued on February 12, 1958 was a valid assessment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: First notice and return invalid due to wrong status; ITO entitled to issue fresh notice in correct HUF status and proceed to valid assessment thereunder.

holdings.text: it was competent for the Income-tax Officer to issue the second notice dated February 12, 1958 and continue proceedings thereon ignoring the return already filed by the assessee in pursuance of the first notice under the same section

anchor.surface_text: The question presented for determination in this appeal is whether it was competent for the Income-tax Officer to issue the second notice dated February 12, 1958 and continue proceedings thereon ignoring the return already filed by the assessee in pursuance of the first notice under the same section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Competence affirmed as first proceedings invalid; second notice corrects status error enabling valid jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: In this state of facts we are of opinion that the proceeding taken under the first notice under s. 34 of the Act was invalid and ultra vires.

We accordingly allow this appeal, set aside, the judgment of the High Court of Andhra Pradesh dated April 14, 1964 and hold that the question of law referred to the High Court should be answered in the a

edges.explanation: The holding affirmatively states that Individual and HUF are separate units of assessment and a wrongly issued notice under s. 34 invalidates proceedings, directly addressing the issue.

anchor.surface_text: Under the scheme of the Income-tax Act the Individual and the Hindu Undivided Family are treated as separate units of assess- ment and if a notice under s. 34 of the Act is wrongly issued to the assessee in the status of an individual and not in the correct status of Hindu Undivided Family the notice is illegal and all proceedings taken under that notice are ultra vires and without jurisdiction.

We accordingly allow this appeal, set aside, the judgment of the High Court of Andhra Pradesh dated April 14, 1964 and hold that the question of law referred to the High Court should be answered in the a

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of the opinion that the Income-tax Officer was legally justified in ignoring the first notice issued under s. 34 of the Act and the return filed by the assessee in response to that notice and consequently the assessment made by the Income- tax Officer in pursuance of the second notice issued on February 12, 1958 was a valid assessment.

We accordingly allow this appeal, set aside, the judgment of the High Court of Andhra Pradesh dated April 14, 1964 and hold that the question of law referred to the High Court should be answered in the a

anchor.surface_text: The question presented for determination in this appeal is whether it was competent for the Income-tax Officer to issue the second notice dated February 12, 1958 and continue proceedings thereon ignoring the return already filed by the assessee in pursuance of the first notice under the same section.
